# ALEXIS: PHYSICAL PRESENCE PROFILE

## NARRATIVE

Alexis moves through space like someone perpetually auditioning for a role he's already cast himself in. His physicality is a carefully orchestrated performance of capability—every gesture calculated to project mastery, yet underneath runs a current of restless tension that betrays the constant self-monitoring. He inherited his mother's performer's awareness of how bodies occupy attention; he watches himself being watched, even when alone. This hypervigilance manifests as a controlled, almost economical movement style: nothing wasted, nothing accidental. His long hair becomes part of this choreography—he uses it strategically, a toss of the head to punctuate confidence, a sweep across his shoulder when regrouping after uncertainty. But there's a brittleness to this control. When dismissed or doubted, his movements become sharper, more aggressive; he'll take on physical challenges with an almost punitive intensity, as if his body must prove what his worth cannot. His father's chronic pain from the construction accident lives in Alexis's body as a phantom fear—he moves with the unconscious awareness of someone terrified of becoming immobilized, of his physical form betraying him. This drives a paradoxical physicality: he pushes his body to extremes to prove it won't fail him, yet carries an underlying dread that one day it will. In intimate moments with Cameron, his carefully constructed posture softens slightly; his movements become less performative and more genuine. But the moment criticism enters, his walls rebuild instantly—his spine straightens, his jaw tightens, and he defaults back to the invulnerable version of himself.

His spatial awareness is acute and defensive. He positions himself strategically in rooms—always noting exits, always maintaining sightlines, always aware of who has authority or advantage in the space. This isn't paranoia; it's the learned behavior of someone whose identity depends on never being caught off-guard. When climbing, this translates into meticulous movement—each handhold tested, each footfall deliberate. But in social situations, the same hypervigilance creates a subtle tension in his shoulders and neck, a readiness that never fully dissipates. His hands are rarely still; they gesture expressively when he's engaged and confident, but when threatened or uncertain, they become tools of distraction—fidgeting, adjusting, controlling. He uses his hands to maintain dominance in conversation, often gesturing in ways that subtly claim space or redirect attention. His breathing is controlled but shallow when stressed; he's learned to regulate it as a form of emotional management, which means his chest rarely rises and falls naturally—it's another performance, another mechanism of control. Even his rest is active; Alexis doesn't truly relax. He dozes rather than sleeps deeply, alert to potential threats or opportunities. His body language says: *I am capable, I am in control, I am worthy of attention*—but his nervous system constantly whispers the opposite.

---
